The cells of Algibacter pectinivorans are Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming. They are rod-shaped and motile, with gliding motility. The optimal growth temperature for this bacterium is around 25-30Â°C.

The ecological role of Algibacter pectinivorans in the marine environment is likely related to its ability to break down and utilize complex polysaccharides, such as pectin, thereby contributing to the recycling of organic matter in the algal-associated microbial communities.
